pageContext.claim: “I hope the people over at the Fed will read today’s Wall Street Journal Editorial before they make yet another mistake. Also, don't let the market become any more illiquid than it already is. Stop with the 50 B’s. Feel the market, don't just go by meaningless numbers. Good luck!”
pageContext.analysis: Trump’s reference to $50 billion appears to be about the Fed’s unwinding of its program known as quantitative easing (QE) — large-scale purchases of assets by central banks. During the financial crisis of 2008-2009, the Fed purchased trillions of dollars of government bonds and mortgage-backed securities as part of a low-interest policy that effectively brought interest rates to zero. Now that the economy has recovered and is doing well, the Fed is trying to unwind its positions, mainly by letting bonds mature without reinvesting them.
